default: (a) a {@item shortbow|phb} and {@item quiver|phb} of {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows} or (b) a {@item shortsword|phb}
(a) a {@item burglar's pack|phb}, (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}, or (c) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}
{@item Leather armor|phb}, two {@item dagger|phb|daggers}, and {@item thieves' tools|phb}

fluff.name: Rogue
entries: Signaling for her companions to wait, a halfling creeps forward through the dungeon hall. She presses an ear to the door, then pulls out a set of tools and picks the lock in the blink of an eye. Then she disappears into the shadows as her fighter friend moves forward to kick the door open.

A human lurks in the shadows of an alley while his accomplice prepares for her part in the ambush. When their target—a notorious slaver—passes the alleyway, the accomplice cries out, the slaver comes to investigate, and the assassin's blade cuts his throat before he can make a sound.

Suppressing a giggle, a gnome waggles her fingers and magically lifts the key ring from the guard's belt. In a moment, the keys are in her hand, the cell door is open, and she and her companions are free to make their escape.

Rogues rely on skill, stealth, and their foes' vulnerabilities to get the upper hand in any situation. They have a knack for finding the solution to just about any problem, demonstrating a resourcefulness and versatility that is the cornerstone of any successful adventuring party.

entries.name: Skill and Precision
entries: Rogues devote as much effort to mastering the use of a variety of skills as they do to perfecting their combat abilities, giving them a broad expertise that few other characters can match. Many rogues focus on stealth and deception, while others refine the skills that help them in a dungeon environment, such as climbing, finding and disarming traps, and opening locks.

When it comes to combat, rogues prioritize cunning over brute strength. A rogue would rather make one precise strike, placing it exactly where the attack will hurt the target most, than wear an opponent down with a barrage of attacks. Rogues have an almost supernatural knack for avoiding danger, and a few learn magical tricks to supplement their other abilities.

entries.name: A Shady Living
entries: Every town and city has its share of rogues. Most of them live up to the worst stereotypes of the class, making a living as burglars, assassins, cutpurses, and con artists. Often, these scoundrels are organized into thieves' guilds or crime families. Plenty of rogues operate independently, but even they sometimes recruit apprentices to help them in their scams and heists. A few rogues make an honest living as locksmiths, investigators, or exterminators, which can be a dangerous job in a world where dire rats—and wererats—haunt the sewers.

As adventurers, rogues fall on both sides of the law. Some are hardened criminals who decide to seek their fortune in treasure hoards, while others take up a life of adventure to escape from the law. Some have learned and perfected their skills with the explicit purpose of infiltrating ancient ruins and hidden crypts in search of treasure.

entries.name: Creating a Rogue
entries: As you create your rogue character, consider the character's relationship to the law. Do you have a criminal past—or present? Are you on the run from the law or from an angry thieves' guild master? Or did you leave your guild in search of bigger risks and bigger rewards? Is it greed that drives you in your adventures, or some other desire or ideal?

What was the trigger that led you away from your previous life? Did a great con or heist gone terribly wrong cause you to reevaluate your career? Maybe you were lucky and a successful robbery gave you the coin you needed to escape the squalor of your life. Did wanderlust finally call you away from your home? Perhaps you suddenly found yourself cut off from your family or your mentor, and you had to find a new means of support. Or maybe you made a new friend—another member of your adventuring party—who showed you new possibilities for earning a living and employing your particular talents.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a rogue quickly by following these suggestions. First, Dexterity should be your highest ability score. Make Intelligence your next-highest if you want to excel at Investigation or plan to take up the Arcane Trickster archetype. Choose Charisma instead if you plan to emphasize deception and social interaction. Second, choose the {@background charlatan} background.
People forget that the entire point of venturing down into a dusty tomb is to bring back the prizes hidden away there. Fighting is for fools. Dead men can't spend their fortunes.

When brute force won't get the job done, or when magic isn't available or appropriate, the rogue rises to the fore. With skills tied to stealth, subterfuge, and trickery, rogues can get into and out of trouble in ways that few other characters can emulate.

Some rogues who turn to adventuring are former criminals who have decided that dodging monsters is preferable to remaining one step ahead of the law. Others are professional killers in search of a profitable application of their talents between contracts. Some simply love the thrill of overcoming any challenge that stands in their way.

On adventures, a rogue is likely to mix an outwardly cautious approach—few rogues enjoy combat—with a ravenous hunger for loot. Most of the time, in a rogue's mind, taking up arms against a creature is not about killing the creature but about becoming the new owner of its treasure.
The following sections explore certain facets of what it means to be a rogue, which you can use to add depth to your character.

entries.name: Guilty Pleasures
entries: Most of what rogues do revolves around obtaining treasure and preventing others from doing the same. Little gets in the way of attaining those goals, except that many rogues are enticed away from that path by a compulsion that clouds their thinking—an irresistible need that must be satisfied, even if doing so is risky.

A rogue's guilty pleasure could be the acquisition of a physical item, something to be experienced, or a way of conducting oneself at certain times. One rogue might not be able to pass up any loot made of silver, for instance, even if said loot is hanging around the neck of a castle guard. Another one can't go through a day in the city without lifting a purse or two, just to keep in practice.
What's the one form of temptation that your rogue character can't resist when the opportunity presents itself, even if giving into it might mean trouble for you and your companions?

entries.caption: Guilty Pleasures
rows: A smile from a pretty face
A new ring for your finger
The chance to deflate someone's ego
Adding to your collection of exotic coins

entries.name: Adversaries
entries: Naturally, those who enforce the law are bound to come up against those who break it, and it's the rare rogue who isn't featured on at least one wanted poster. Beyond that, it's in the nature of their profession that rogues often come into contact with criminal elements, whether out of choice or necessity. Some of those people can be adversaries too, and they're likely to be harder to deal with than the average member of the city watch.

If your character's backstory doesn't already include a personage of this sort, you could work with your DM to come up with a reason why an adversary has appeared in your life. Perhaps you've been the subject of scrutiny for a while from someone who wants to use you for nefarious purposes and has just now become known to you. Such an incident could be the basis for an upcoming adventure.
Does your rogue character have an adversary who also happens to be a criminal? If so, how is this relationship affecting your life?

entries.caption: Adversaries
rows: The pirate captain on whose ship you once served; what you call moving on, the captain calls mutiny
A master spy to whom you unwittingly fed bad information, which led to the assassination of the wrong target
The master of the local thieves' guild, who wants you to join the organization or leave town
An art collector who uses illegal means to acquire masterpieces
A fence who uses you as a messenger to set up illicit meetings
The proprietor of an illegal pit fighting arena where you once took bets

entries.name: Benefactor
entries: Few rogues make it far in life before needing someone's help, which means thereafter owing that benefactor a significant debt.

If your character's backstory doesn't already include a personage of this sort, you could work with your DM to determine why a benefactor has appeared in your life. Perhaps you benefited from something your benefactor did for you without realizing who was responsible, and that person has now just become known to you. Who helped you in the past, whether or not you knew it at the time, and what do you owe that person as recompense?

entries.caption: Benefactors
rows: A smuggler kept you from getting caught but lost a valuable shipment in doing so. Now you owe that person an equally valuable favor.
The Beggar King has hidden you from your pursuers many times, in return for future considerations.
A magistrate once kept you out of jail in return for information on a powerful crime lord.
Your parents used their savings to bail you out of trouble in your younger days and are now destitute.
A dragon didn't eat you when it had a chance, and in return you promised to set aside choice pieces of treasure for it.
A druid once helped you out of a tight spot; now any random animal you see could be that benefactor, perhaps come to claim a return favor.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: Choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus is doubled for any {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir} you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: You know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don't need {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir}, and you don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: During your rogue training you learned thieves' cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves' cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves' guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir} on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the {@action Dash|Ishiir}, {@action Disengage|Ishiir}, or {@action Hide|Ishiir} action.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action: Aim
entries: You gain an additional way to use your Cunning Action: carefully aiming your next attack. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, you give yourself {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on your next {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} on the current turn. You can use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir} only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use the {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype
entries: You choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities from the list of available archetypes. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Martial Mastery
entries: You gain the mastery benefits for two {@filter weapons|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;!light;!medium;!heavy} of your choice as well as an {@filter armor|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;light;medium;heavy} type (see {@variantrule Armor Mastery|Ishiir} and {@variantrule Weapon Mastery|Ishiir} variant rules). You must be {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|proficient} in the chosen weapons and armor. If you possess the Unarmored Defense feature, you may {@optfeature Unarmored Defense|Ishiir|choose it} in place of an armor type.
You can change your choices when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to halve the attack's damage against you.

classFeature.name: Cunning Strike
entries: You have developed ways to hamper your foes when you use your Sneak Attack. When you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can add one of the following Cunning Strike effects. Each effect has a die cost, which is the number of Sneak Attack damage dice you must forego to add the effect. You remove the die before rolling, and the effect occurs immediately after the attack’s damage is dealt. For example, if you add the Lacerate effect, remove 1d6 from the Sneak Attack’s damage before rolling.
If a Cunning Strike effect requires a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, the DC equals 8 + your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Bonus + your Dexterity or Strength modifier (your choice).

items.name: Distract (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, or it cannot take {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir|Reactions} until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Lacerate (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target must make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. On a failed save, the target is {@condition Lacerated|Ishiir} for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the {@condition Lacerated|Ishiir} target can repeat the save, ending the effect on on a success.

items.name: Trip (Cost: 1d6)
entries: If the target is no more than 1 size larger than you, it must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be knocked {@condition Prone|Ishiir}.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain the benefit of Expertise.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain dangers. When you're subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and only half damage if you fail. You can't use this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} condition.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: Whenever you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir} that uses one of your skill or tool proficiencies, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: You gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Improved Cunning Strike
entries: You can use up to two Cunning Strike effects when you deal Sneak Attack damage, paying the die cost for each effect.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: You gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Devious Strikes
entries: You have honed yourself in new ways to use your Sneak Attack. The following effects are now among your Cunning Strike options.

items.name: Daze (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Dazed|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

items.name: Knock Out (Cost: 6d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or drop {@condition Unconscious|Ishiir} for 1d4 hours or until it takes damage.

items.name: Obscure (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Blinded|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Slippery Mind
entries: You have acquired greater mental strength. You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in Wisdom and Charisma {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: You gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Elusive
entries: You are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} has {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} against you while you aren't {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: You have a marvelous knack for succeeding when you need to. If you fail a D20 Test, you can turn the roll into a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Trickster
entries: Some Rogues enhance their fine-honed skills of stealth and agility with spells, learning magical tricks to aid them in their trade. Some Arcane Tricksters use their talents as pickpockets and burglars, while others are pranksters.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells. The information below details how you use those rules as an Arcane Trickster.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips: {@spell Mage Hand|Ishiir} and two other cantrips of your choice from the {@filter Wizard spell list|spells|class=wizard (Ishiir)|source=Ishiir}.
Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one of your cantrips, except {@spell Mage Hand|Ishiir}, with another Wizard cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Rogue level 10, you learn another Wizard cantrip of your choice, as shown in this subclass' progression table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level.
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose three level 1 Wizard spells.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Wizard spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Arcane Trickster Spellcasting table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 7 Rogue, your list of prepared spells can include five Wizard spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells.
entries: Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Wizard spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability.
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus.
entries: You can use an Arcane Focus as a Spellcasting Focus for your Wizard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Mage Hand Legerdemain
entries: When you cast {@spell Mage Hand|Ishiir}, you can cast it as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, and you can make the spectral hand {@condition Invisible|Ishiir}. You can control the hand as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, and through it, you can make Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir|checks}.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Ambush
entries: If you are hidden from a creature when you cast a spell on it, the creature has {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on any {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} it makes against the spell this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Versatile Trickster
entries: When you use your Cunning Strike, you can instead choose a creature other than the original target of your attack that you can see within 5 ft of your mage hand.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Thief
entries: You gain the ability to magically steal the knowledge of how to cast a spell from another spellcaster.

Immediately after a creature casts a spell that targets you or includes you in its area of effect, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to force the creature to make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} with its spellcasting ability. The DC equals your spell save DC. On a failed save, you negate the spell's effect, and you steal the knowledge of the spell. For the next 7 days, you have the spell prepared. You can cast this spell once without expending a spell slot. You can also cast this spell normally if you have spell slots for its level (it doesn't have to be a Wizard spell). The creature can't cast it until the 7 days have passed.
Once you have stolen a spell with this feature, you can't use it again until you have finished a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Assassin
entries: You focus your training on the grim art of death. Those who adhere to this archetype are diverse—hired killers, spies, bounty hunters, and even specially anointed priests trained to exterminate the enemies of their deity. Stealth, poison, and disguise help you eliminate your foes with deadly efficiency.
Your archetype grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Assassinate
entries: You are at your deadliest when you get the drop on your enemies. You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against any creature that hasn't taken a turn in the combat yet. When you use your Sneak Attack against a creature on the first turn of combat that hasn't acted yet or that you are hidden, the number of d6s that you roll as part of your Sneak Attack's damage increases by an amount equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with the {@item disguise kit|phb} and the {@item poisoner's kit|phb}.

subclassFeature.name: Preparation
entries: You have {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in initiative.

subclassFeature.name: Roving Aim
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} isn't reduced to 0 by using Steady Aim.

subclassFeature.name: Death Dealer
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Envenom (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Poisoned|Ishiir} for 1 minute. It can repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} at the end of every one of its turns, ending the effect on a success. You must have a {@item Poisoner's Kit|Ishiir} on your person to use this effect. Alternatively, you can apply a poison that you currently have on your person. If you do so, the save DC of the poison changes to your Cunning Strike save DC if it is normally lower.

items.name: Silence (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be unable to speak or produce sound with its voice until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Lethality
entries: The critical range for your weapon attacks increases by 1.
Additionally, you can apply the extra damage from your Assassinate class feature even after the first turn of combat, provided that you are hidden from the target or it is suffering from a condition.

entries.subclassFeature: True Hide in Plain Sight|Rogue|Ishiir|Changeling Infiltrator|Ishiir|3

subclassFeature.name: Cunning Step
entries: When you use your Cunning Action class feature, you can also choose to teleport 30 ft to an unoccupied space that you can see. You can choose to do so immediately after or before applying the effect of Cunning Action. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: True Hide in Plain Sight
entries: You may choose to take the {@action Hide|Ishiir} action and may stay hidden even when the conditions normally wouldn't allow you to, such as when you are in direct line of sight of a creature or you are standing in bright light. If you do so, you take a -5 penalty to your Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to hide. Depending on the circumstances, the DM may impose this penalty multiple times.
This feature does not allow you to bypass the conditions for hiding against creatures that perceive you with senses other than mundane sight or are able to perceive the true form of a shapechanger.

subclassFeature.name: Slippery Escape
entries: When you take damage, you may use your {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to immediately teleport 30 feet to a place that you can see and attempt to hide.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} and regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Confounding Strikes
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Charm (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target has to succeed on a Wisddom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Charmed|Ishiir} by you for 1 minute. It can repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} at the end of each of its turns to end the effect.

items.name: Confuse (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target has to succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Confused|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Twilight Dancer
entries: True Hide in Plain Sight no longer carries penalties. Additionally, you now regain all uses of your Cunning Step and Slippery Escape on a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Inquisitor
entries: As an archetypal Inquisitive, you excel at rooting out secrets and unraveling mysteries. You rely on your sharp eye for detail, but also on your finely honed ability to read the words and deeds of other creatures to determine their true intent. You excel at defeating creatures that hide among and prey upon ordinary folk, and your mastery of lore and your keen deductions make you well equipped to expose and end hidden evils.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast spells. The information below details how you use those rules as an Inquisitor.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips of your choice from the {@filter Cleric spell list|spells|class=cleric (Ishiir)|source=Ishiir}.
Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one of your cantrips, with another Cleric cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Rogue level 10, you learn another Cleric cantrip of your choice, as shown in this subclass' progression table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Inquisitor Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of 1st+ Level.
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose three level 1 Cleric spells.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Inquisitor Spellcasting table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Cleric spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Inquisitor Spellcasting table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 7 Rogue, your list of prepared spells can include five Cleric spells of level 1 or 2 in any combination.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells.
entries: Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Cleric spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability.
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Cleric spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus.
entries: You can use a Holy Symbol as a Spellcasting Focus for your Cleric spells.

subclassFeature.name: Inquisitor's Gaze
entries: When you use Cunning Action: Aim, you can choose one creature you can see. You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the first {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} against that creature each turn for 1 minute instead. This effect ends early if you can no longer see the target, you are {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir}, you perform a hostile action against a different creature (such as an attack or forcing it to make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}), or you use Inquisitor's Gaze on a different creature.

subclassFeature.name: Piercing Gaze
entries: You add your Wisdom modifier to Initiative rolls and to {@skill Investigation} and {@skill Intimidation} {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir|checks}.

subclassFeature.name: Persecutor's Strikes
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Brand (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or lose the ability to cast spells and turn {@condition Invisible|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

items.name: Castigate (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target must succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Frightened|Ishiir} of you until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Unflinching Gaze
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on all {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws} caused by the target of your Inquisitor's Gaze.

subclassFeature.name: Mastermind
entries: Your focus is on people and on the influence and secrets they have. Many spies, courtiers, and schemers follow this archetype, leading lives of intrigue. Words are your weapons as often as knives or poison, and secrets and favors are some of your favorite treasures.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Intrigue
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with the {@item disguise kit|phb}, the {@item forgery kit|phb}. Additionally, you can use your Intelligence for {@skill Deception}, {@skill Insight}, {@skill Intimidation}, and {@skill Persuasion} {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir|checks}.

subclassFeature.name: Master of Tactics
entries: You can use the {@action Help|Ishiir} action as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}. Additionally, when you use the {@action Help|Ishiir} action to aid an ally in attacking a creature, the target of that attack can be within 60 feet of you, rather than within 5 feet of you, if the target can see or hear you.

subclassFeature.name: Swift Tactics
entries: Your add your Intelligence modifier to Initiative rolls.
Additionally, you can use your Cunning Action and Master of Tactics as part of the same {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Infiltration Expertise
entries: You can unfailingly create false identities for yourself. You must spend seven days and 25 gp to establish the history, profession, and affiliations for an identity. You can't establish an identity that belongs to someone else. For example, you might acquire appropriate clothing, letters of introduction, and official-looking certification to establish yourself as a member of a trading house from a remote city so you can insinuate yourself into the company of other wealthy merchants.
Thereafter, if you adopt the new identity as a disguise, other creatures believe you to be that person until given an obvious reason not to.

You also gain the ability to unerringly mimic another person's speech, writing, and behavior. You must spend at least three hours studying these three components of the person's behavior, listening to speech, examining handwriting, and observing mannerism.

Your ruse is indiscernible to the casual observer. If a wary creature suspects something is amiss, you have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on any Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check you make to avoid detection.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Strikes
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Confound (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target must make a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against you until the start of your next turn while any of your allies are within reach of its attacks.

items.name: Instigate (Cost: 3d6)
entries: An ally of your choice within 60 feet of you can use its {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to make a weapon attack against the same target, provided it is within reach.

subclassFeature.name: Labyrinthine Mind
entries: Your thoughts can't be read by telepathy or other means, unless you allow it. You can present false thoughts by succeeding on a Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check contested by the mind reader's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. You are also {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir|Immune} to the {@condition Charmed|Ishiir} condition.
Additionally, no matter what you say, magic that would determine if you are telling the truth indicates you are being truthful if you so choose, and you can't be compelled to tell the truth by magic.

If you fail a Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to reroll the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and add your Intelligence modifier to it, even if it was already added, taking whichever result was higher.
You can use this feature three times and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Phantom
entries: Many rogues walk a fine line between life and death, risking their own lives and taking the lives of others. While adventuring on that line, some rogues discover a mystical connection to death itself. These rogues take knowledge from the dead and become immersed in negative energy, eventually becoming like ghosts. Thieves' guilds value them as highly effective information gatherers and spies.

Many shadar-kai of the Shadowfell are masters of these macabre techniques, and some are willing to teach this path. In places like Thay in the Forgotten Realms and Karrnath in Eberron, where many necromancers practice their craft, a Phantom can become a wizard's confidant and right hand. In temples of gods of death, the Phantom might work as an agent to track down those who try to cheat death and to recover knowledge that might otherwise be lost to the grave.
How did you discover this grim power? Did you sleep in a graveyard and awaken to your new abilities? Or did you cultivate them in a temple or thieves' guild dedicated to a deity of death?

subclassFeature.name: Wails from the Grave
entries: As you nudge someone closer to the grave, you can channel the power of death to push them over the threshold or harm someone else as well. When you deal your Sneak Attack damage to a creature on your turn, you can cause that creature to take additional damage. Alternatively, you can target a second creature that you can see within 30 feet of the first creature. Roll half the number of Sneak Attack dice for your level (round up), the original target or the second creature takes necrotic damage equal to the roll's total, as wails of the dead sound around them for a moment.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Whispers of the Dead
entries: Echoes of those who have died cling to you. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, you can choose one skill or tool {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} that you lack and gain it, as a ghostly presence shares its knowledge with you. You lose this {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} when you use this feature to choose a different {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} that you lack.

subclassFeature.name: Tokens of the Departed
entries: When a life ends in your presence, you're able to snatch a token from the departing soul, a sliver of its life essence that takes physical form: when a creature you can see dies within 30 feet of you, you can open your free hand and cause a Tiny trinket to appear there, a soul trinket. The DM determines the trinket's form or has you roll on the {@item Trinket|phb|Trinkets} table in the {@i Player's Handbook} to generate it. You can have a maximum number of soul trinkets equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and you can't create one while at your maximum.
You can use soul trinkets in the following ways:

items: While a soul trinket is on your person, you have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on death {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws} and Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws}, for your vitality is enhanced by the life essence within the object.
When you deal Sneak Attack damage on your turn, you can destroy one of your soul trinkets that's on your person and then immediately use Wails from the Grave, without expending a use of that feature.

As an {@variantrule Action|Ishiir}, you can destroy one of your soul trinkets, no matter where it's located. When you do so, you can ask the spirit associated with the trinket one question. The spirit appears to you and answers in a language it knew in life. It's under no obligation to be truthful, and it answers as concisely as possible, eager to be free. The spirit knows only what it knew in life, as determined by the DM.

subclassFeature.name: Death's Friend
entries: Your association with death has become so close that you gain the following benefits:

items: When you use your Wails from the Grave, you can deal the necrotic damage to both the first and the second creature.
At the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, a soul trinket appears in your hand if you don't have any soul trinkets, as the spirits of the dead are drawn to you.
You also ignore {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} to necrotic damage from your Wails from the Grave feature and treat {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir} to it as {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} instead.

subclassFeature.name: Ghost Walk
entries: You can phase partially into the realm of the dead, becoming like a ghost. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, you assume a spectral form. While in this form, you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir}, you can hover, and {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} against you. You can also move through creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}, but you take {@damage 1d10} force damage if you end your turn inside a creature or an object.

You stay in this form for 10 minutes or until you end it as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}. To use this feature again, you must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir} or destroy one of your soul trinkets as part of the {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir} you use to activate Ghost Walk.

subclassFeature.name: Scout
entries: You are skilled in stealth and surviving far from the streets of a city, allowing you to scout ahead of your companions during expeditions. Rogues who embrace this archetype are at home in the wilderness and among barbarians and rangers, and many Scouts serve as the eyes and ears of war bands. Ambusher, spy, bounty hunter—these are just a few of the roles that Scouts assume as they range the world.

subclassFeature.name: Skirmisher
entries: You are difficult to pin down during a fight. You can move up to half your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} as a {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} when an enemy ends its turn within 10 feet of you. This movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: You are a master of navigating the natural world, and you react with swift and decisive action when attacked. This grants you the following benefits:

items: You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on initiative rolls.
On your first turn during combat, you have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against creatures that have not yet acted.

entries: In addition, you are skilled at navigating the wilderness. You gain the following benefits when traveling for an hour or more:

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow your group's travel.
Your group can't become lost except by magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Mobility
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} increases by 10 feet. If you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|Ishiir} or {@variantrule Swim Speed|Ishiir}, this increase applies to that {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} as well.

subclassFeature.name: Ambush Master
entries: You excel at leading ambushes and acting first in a fight.

You are {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|proficient} in Initiative. In addition, the first creature you hit during the first round of a combat becomes easier for you and others to strike; {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against that target have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Sudden Strike
entries: When you attack a creature that you are hidden from, you can make an additional attack as part of your attack action. On the first turn of combat, you can apply your Sneak Attack to both of these attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes in the Dark
entries: You can hide even when in plain view, as long as you are in an area of dim light or darkness. Additionally, you can see normally in darkness, both magical and non-magical, to a distance of 60 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Shadowdance
entries: You gain the ability to step from one shadow into another. When you use your Cunning Action while in dim light or darkness, you can teleport up to 60 feet to a different unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. You can apply the effects of your Cunning Action before or after you teleport. This does not count as movement for the purpose of Cunning Action: Aim.

subclassFeature.name: Cunning Action: Umbral Shroud
entries: You gain the ability to use your Cunning Action to shape the shadows around you into a 30-feet radius sphere around your position. The area inside the sphere counts as dim light and persists for 10 minutes. It disappears early if you become {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} or if its area overlaps with light created by a spell of 3rd level or higher.
You can only have one Umbral Shroud active at a time.

subclassFeature.name: Dagger in the Dark
entries: While you are in dim light or darkness, you can reduce the cost of any feature that uses your Sneak Attack dice by 1 (to a minimum of 0). You can do so only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Umbral Strikes
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Curse (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target has to make a Charisma {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be cursed until the end of your next turn. For the duration of the effect, the target must roll a {@dice d4} every time it rolls an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} or {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and subtract the result from the total.

items.name: Enfeeble (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target has to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or deal half damage with weapon attacks until the end of your next turn.
Additionally, while you are in darkness, you can reduce the cost of any feature that uses your Sneak Attack dice by 2 instead of 1 (to a minimum of 0). You can do so only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Nightwalker
entries: You gain the ability to adopt a shadowy form as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir} for 10 minutes. While in this form, {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} against you, you gain the Spiderclimb trait, and you double your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} if you start your turn in an area of dim light or darkness.
You can use this feature once and must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir} before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Soulknife
entries: Most assassins strike with physical weapons, and many burglars and spies use {@item thieves' tools|PHB} to infiltrate secure locations. In contrast, a Soulknife strikes and infiltrates with the mind, cutting through barriers both physical and psychic. These rogues discover psionic power within themselves and channel it to do their roguish work. They find easy employment as members of thieves' guilds, though they are often mistrusted by rogues who are leery of anyone using strange mind powers to conduct their business. Most governments would also be happy to employ a Soulknife as a spy.

Amid the trees of ancient forests on the Material Plane and in the Feywild, some wood elves walk the path of the Soulknife, serving as silent, lethal guardians of their woods. In the endless war among the gith, a githzerai is encouraged to become a Soulknife when stealth is required against the githyanki foe.

As a Soulknife, your psionic abilities might have haunted you since you were a child, only revealing their full potential as you experienced the stress of adventure. Or you might have sought out a reclusive order of psychic adepts and spent years learning how to manifest your power.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Blades
entries: You can manifest your psionic power as shimmering blades of psychic energy. Whenever you make a weapon attack, you can manifest a psychic blade from your free hand and make the attack with that blade. This magic blade is a simple melee weapon with the finesse and thrown properties. It has a normal range of 60 feet and no long range, and on a hit, it deals psychic damage equal to your Psionic Energy Die plus the ability modifier you used for the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}. The blade vanishes immediately after it hits or misses its target, and it leaves no mark on its target if it deals damage.

After you attack with the blade, you can make a melee or ranged weapon attack with a second psychic blade as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir} on the same turn, provided your other hand is free to create it.

subclassFeature.name: Psionic Power
entries: You harbor a wellspring of psionic energy within yourself. This energy is represented by your Psionic Energy dice, which are each a {@dice d6}. You have a number of these dice equal to twice your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and they fuel various psionic powers you have, which are detailed below.

Some of your powers expend the Psionic Energy die they use, as specified in a power's description, and you can't use a power if it requires you to use a die when your dice are all expended. You regain all your expended Psionic Energy dice when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}. In addition, as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, you can regain one expended Psionic Energy die, but you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir|Short} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.
When you reach certain levels in this class, the size of your Psionic Energy dice increases: at 5th level ({@dice d8}), 11th level ({@dice d10}), and 17th level ({@dice d12}).
The powers below use your Psionic Energy dice.

subclassFeature.name: Psi-Bolstered Knack
entries: When your nonpsionic training fails you, your psionic power can help: if you fail an {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir} using a skill or tool with which you have {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir}, you can roll one Psionic Energy die and add the number rolled to the check, potentially turning failure into success. You expend the die only if the roll succeeds.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Whispers
entries: You can establish telepathic communication between yourself and others-perfect for quiet infiltration. As an {@variantrule Action|Ishiir}, choose one or more creatures you can see, up to a number of creatures equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and then roll one Psionic Energy die. For a number of hours equal to the number rolled, the chosen creatures can speak telepathically with you, and you can speak telepathically with them. To send or receive a message (no action required), you and the other creature must be within 1 mile of each other. A creature can't use this telepathy if it can't speak any languages, and a creature can end the telepathic connection at any time (no action required). You and the creature don't need to speak a common language to understand each other.
The first time you use this power after each {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, you don't expend the Psionic Energy die. All other times you use the power, you expend the die.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Veil
entries: You can weave a veil of psychic static to mask yourself. As an {@variantrule Action|Ishiir}, you can magically become {@condition Invisible|Ishiir}, along with anything you are wearing or carrying, for 1 hour or until you dismiss this effect (no action required). This invisibility ends early immediately after you deal damage to a creature or you force a creature to make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}.

If you expend a Psionic Energy Die, you can also affect all creatures of your choice while they are within 20 feet of you. The effect ends early on all affected creatures when any of them deal damage to a creature or force it to make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, unless you expend a Psionic Energy die to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Homing Strikes
entries: If you make an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} with your Psychic Blades and miss the target, you can roll one Psionic Energy die and add the number rolled to the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}. If this causes the attack to hit, you expend the Psionic Energy die.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Teleportation
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, you manifest one of your Psychic Blades, expend one Psionic Energy die and roll it, and throw the blade at an unoccupied space you can see, up to a number of feet away equal to 10 times the number rolled. You then teleport to that space, and the blade vanishes.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Strikes
entries: You learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Chivy (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target must make a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or use its {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to move as far from you as it can, taking the safest route.

items.name: Stupefy (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target must make an Intelligence {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the next {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} it makes before the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Rend Mind
entries: You can sweep your Psychic Blades directly through a creature's mind. When you use your Psychic Blades to deal Sneak Attack damage to a creature, you can force that target to make an Intelligence {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} (DC equal to 8 + your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus + your Dexterity modifier). If the save fails, the target is {@condition Stunned|Ishiir} for 1 minute. The {@condition Stunned|Ishiir} target can repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, unless you expend three Psionic Energy dice to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Swashbuckler
entries: You focus your training on the art of the blade, relying on speed, elegance, and charm in equal parts. While some warriors are brutes clad in heavy armor, your method of fighting looks almost like a performance. Duelists and pirates typically belong to this archetype.
A Swashbuckler excels in single combat, and can fight with two weapons while safely darting away from an opponent.

subclassFeature.name: Fancy Footwork
entries: You learn how to land a strike and then slip away without reprisal. During your turn, if you make a melee attack against a creature, that creature can't make opportunity attacks against you for the rest of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Rakish Audacity
entries: Your confidence propels you into battle. You can give yourself a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your Charisma modifier.

You also gain an additional way to use your Sneak Attack; you don't need {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on your {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} to use Sneak Attack against a creature if it is within your melee reach, no other creatures are within 5 feet of you, and you don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}. All the other rules for Sneak Attack still apply to you.

subclassFeature.name: Panache
entries: You also learn the following new ways to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Disarm (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target has to make a Strength or Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} (target's choice) or drop 1 item of your choice that it is holding. The target has {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on this {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} if it is holding the item with both hands or is at least 1 size larger than you. This feature has no effect against a creature more than 2 sizes larges than you.

items.name: Goad (Cost: 1d6)
entries: The target has to make a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against targets other than you and be unable to make opportunity attacks against targets other than you until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Parrying Stance (Cost: 2d6)
entries: Roll {@dice 2d6}. You gain a bonus to your AC equal to half the number rolled (rounded up) until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Elegant Riposte
entries: When you are currently in your parrying stance and a creature misses you with a melee weapon attack, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|Ishiir} to make a melee weapon against that creature, provided it is within your reach.

subclassFeature.name: Master Duelist
entries: Immediately after you use your Sneak Attack, you can make another attack against the same target with a melee weapon you are holding, provided the target is within your reach and no other creatures are within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Thief
entries: You hone your skills in the larcenous arts. Burglars, bandits, cutpurses, and other criminals typically follow this archetype, but so do rogues who prefer to think of themselves as professional treasure seekers, explorers, delvers, and investigators. In addition to improving your agility and stealth, you learn skills useful for delving into ancient ruins, reading unfamiliar languages, and using magic items you normally couldn't employ.

subclassFeature.name: Fast Hands
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|Ishiir}, you can do one of the following.

items.name: Sleight of Hand.
entries: Make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check to pick a lock or disarm a trap with Thieves' Tools or to pick a pocket.

items.name: Use an Object.
entries: Take the Utilize action, or take the {@action Magic|Ishiir} action to use a magic item that requires that action.

subclassFeature.name: Second-Story Work
entries: You've trained to get into especially hard-to-reach places, granting you these benefits.

items.name: Climber.
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Climb Speed|Ishiir} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir}.

items.name: Jumper.
entries: You can determine your jump distance using your Dexterity rather than your Strength.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Sneak
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on Stealth {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir|checks} and you do not lose the benefits of being Hidden as long as you end your turn behind at least three-quarters cover or heavily obscured.

subclassFeature.name: Use Magic Device
entries: You've learned how to maximize use of magic items, granting you the following benefits.

items.name: Attunement.
entries: You can attune to up to four magic items at once.

items.name: Charges.
entries: Whenever you use a magic item property that expends charges, roll {@dice 1d6}. On a roll of 6, you use the property without expending the charges.

items.name: Scrolls.
entries: You can use any Spell Scroll, using Intelligence as your spellcasting ability for the spell. If the spell is a cantrip or a level 1 spell, you can cast it reliably. If the scroll contains a higher-level spell, you must first succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check (DC 10 plus the spell's level). On a successful check, you cast the spell from the scroll. On a failed check, the scroll disintegrates.

subclassFeature.name: Thief's Reflexes
entries: You have become adept at laying ambushes and quickly escaping danger. You can take two turns during the first round of any combat. You take your first turn at your normal initiative and your second turn at your initiative minus 10. You can't use this feature when you are {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised}.

subclassFeature.name: Back Alley Bruiser
entries: You don't need {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} to use your Sneak Attack against a creature if its within your melee reach, none of its allies are within 5 feet of it, and you don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}. All the other rules for Sneak Attack still apply to you.
Additionally, you can Sneak Attack with any melee weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Bruiser's Arsenal
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in martial weapons, medium armor, shields, as well as the {@skill Intimidation} skill. If you are already {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir|proficient} in {@skill Intimidation}, you gain expertise in it.

subclassFeature.name: Tough as Nails
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir|Saving Throws} and your hit point maximum increases by 1 for every level in this class and increases by 1 again when you gain a level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Mob Rule
entries: You use your Cunning Strike feature, you learn the following new way to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Bully (Cost: 3d6)
entries: The target has to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or all {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against it have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

items.name: Cow (Cost: 2d6)
entries: The target has to make a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir|Attack Rolls} against you.

Additionally, you can reduce the die cost of any of your Cunning Strike options by 1 (to a minimum of 0) while none of your target's allies are within 5 feet of it and at least 1 of your allies is within their melee reach. You can do so only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Brutal Beating
entries: When you take the Attack action and use your Sneak Attack, you can immediately make another attack. If the target is suffering from a condition, you can add half your Sneak Attack dice (rounded down) to that attack.
You also learn the following new way to use your Sneak Attack:

items.name: Stun (Cost: 6d6)
entries: The target has to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Stunned|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.
